@graph.involvedParties: Credit Suisse Securities (USA) LLC v. Billing
In re Initial Public Offering Antitrust Litigation
@graph.reasoning: The District Court agreed with petitioners and dismissed the complaints against them.

@graph.involvedParties: Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
@graph.reasoning: The Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reversed, however, and reinstated the complaints.
Sometimes regulatory statutes explicitly state whether they preclude application of the antitrust laws.
Where regulatory statutes are silent in respect to antitrust, however, courts must determine whether, and in what respects, they implicitly preclude application of the antitrust laws.

@graph.involvedParties: Verizon Communications Inc. v. Law Offices of Curtis V. Trinko, LLP
@graph.reasoning: Analyzing the antitrust saving clause of the Telecommunications Act.
The Court wrote that, where possible, courts should “reconcil[e] the operation of both [i. e., antitrust and securities] statutory schemes . . . rather than holding one completely ousted.”
An “implied repeal” of the antitrust laws would be found only “where there is a ‘plain repugnancy between the antitrust and regulatory provisions.’”

@graph.involvedParties: Otter Tail Power Co. v. United States
Phonetele, Inc. v. American Tel. & Tel. Co.
